body:
Sorry for the long post, but it requires a lot of explanation and data to be understood.

This all started two days ago when I found a new Minecraft YouTuber called "[Fundy](https://www.youtube.com/fundy)" while watching other stuff like AntVenom. Of course I saw it in the "suggested videos" sidebar. The majority of the stuff was stupid mods, and it seemed like a decent channel, although the 1M+ subscribers surprised me a little. But then I wondered why I hadn't seen them before, so I checked their older videos and...wait, that's not right, they only had 34 total, the first one being...*this December*?!

UPDATE: I found more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

[GeorgeNotFound](https://www.youtube.com/c/GeorgeNotFound/channels)

[Dream](https://www.youtube.com/Dreamm)

END UPDATE

I first assumed they just removed their older videos for some reason, so I did a bit more digging and found his [twitter account](https://twitter.com/fundylive). And behold, the video from this December really *was* the first video, at which point the channel had just hit 1k subscribers! No wonder I hadn't seen them before. But now I was really confused, as all the popular channels I've ever watched took an insanely long amount of time to build up their fanbase, with lots of videos in the process. Most popular channels took over a year to get the first 10k subs, and had average beginnings, but this guy just got hundreds of thousands of subs out of nowhere, reaching 1M in 6 months with only 34 videos, and their first videos were insanely high quality for a beginner *and* they and all the videos up till now got 1-5 million views every single time, all without any major SEO (search engine optimization) techniques! For comparison, the most popular channels usually get about 1-400k views per video. He literally has a 100% virality rate, as a *beginner*, which didn't sit right with me.

[1k subscribers in December, then another 1k+ the next day](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1212051427079667720)

[1 million views on his first few videos in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1216193854816313344)

[50k subs in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1221755156087353345)

[100k in March](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1240043074639876097)

[200k in April](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1255536659707412483)

[270k a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1261283315417518081)

After that it's literally about 100k per week

[400k a month later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1274152818891526147)

[700k 2 weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1277599336784891904)

[1 million a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1284901504281968641)

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch were created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he *did* have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

[Proof of older videos that were removed](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1178008635223339008)

For reference, here's the statistics of his *super legitimate* growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the ["living in a van" channel](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg).

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

> Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

> An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

> YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

> Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

> She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see on this guild when going to post this is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

body:
Don't you think it's at least a little bit suspicious how YT's algorithm suddenly started promoting them everywhere as soon as they began uploading, without any SEO or prior activity? And how they had such high quality editing and clickbaity ideas as total beginners and YT noobs?

Plus, there are plenty of older videos that have the same ideas as them, and even the ones that are way better than theirs have far less views over years as compared to the few days or weeks theirs have existed.

And most other channels, even the super popular ones, can't ever get in the suggested videos panel no matter what they do, yet Fundy and Dream get like half the space without even trying.

post.body:
Sorry for the long post, but it requires a lot of explanation and data to be understood.

This all started two days ago when I found a new Minecraft YouTuber called "[Fundy](https://www.youtube.com/fundy)" while watching other stuff like AntVenom. Of course I saw it in the "suggested videos" sidebar. The majority of the stuff was stupid mods, and it seemed like a decent channel, although the 1M+ subscribers surprised me a little. But then I wondered why I hadn't seen them before, so I checked their older videos and...wait, that's not right, they only had 34 total, the first one being...*this December*?!

UPDATE: I found more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

[GeorgeNotFound](https://www.youtube.com/c/GeorgeNotFound/channels)

[Dream](https://www.youtube.com/Dreamm)

END UPDATE

I first assumed they just removed their older videos for some reason, so I did a bit more digging and found his [twitter account](https://twitter.com/fundylive). And behold, the video from this December really *was* the first video, at which point the channel had just hit 1k subscribers! No wonder I hadn't seen them before. But now I was really confused, as all the popular channels I've ever watched took an insanely long amount of time to build up their fanbase, with lots of videos in the process. Most popular channels took over a year to get the first 10k subs, and had average beginnings, but this guy just got hundreds of thousands of subs out of nowhere, reaching 1M in 6 months with only 34 videos, and their first videos were insanely high quality for a beginner *and* they and all the videos up till now got 1-5 million views every single time, all without any major SEO (search engine optimization) techniques! For comparison, the most popular channels usually get about 1-400k views per video. He literally has a 100% virality rate, as a *beginner*, which didn't sit right with me.

[1k subscribers in December, then another 1k+ the next day](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1212051427079667720)

[1 million views on his first few videos in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1216193854816313344)

[50k subs in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1221755156087353345)

[100k in March](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1240043074639876097)

[200k in April](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1255536659707412483)

[270k a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1261283315417518081)

After that it's literally about 100k per week

[400k a month later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1274152818891526147)

[700k 2 weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1277599336784891904)

[1 million a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1284901504281968641)

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch were created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he *did* have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

[Proof of older videos that were removed](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1178008635223339008)

For reference, here's the statistics of his *super legitimate* growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the ["living in a van" channel](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg).

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

> Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

> An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

> YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

> Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

> She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see on this guild when going to post this is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

body:
ok I don't know if this means anything but when I saw you mentioned Dream I went to check on his speedrun.com profile because he's currently the world record holder for random seed Minecraft and like, thats an *active* catagory (as in people are still trying to beat the record) so *surely* he's done a *bunch* of runs right?


...his profile was made 4 months ago, is *very* blank (most notably - there's no link to a streaming platform which is kinda normal nowadays), was last active a month ago (this also includes the site's forums but as I have no idea where the minecraft speedrunning community is based so that that with a pinch of salt) and has a total of *4* runs on it, all of which were world records in the same category and all have polished youtube videos showcasing them done in his standard style. For comparison the guy below him on the leaderboard whose account was made only a month before Dream's has *24* runs (and a *lot* more attempts) in more than one category, not all of them were world records and was last active a few hours ago.  

Now I don't follow minecraft speedrunning but I'd *love* to know if anyone who does has actually heard or interacted with Dream because this is...kinda weird. Like I know streamers will sometimes try world records for fun but for someone who doesn't seem to have a background in speedrunning to not only get the world record *3 times* and then *hold* it for over a month in a category that was updated as recently as yesterday seems *weird*. And look, maybe I'm overreacting because I'm used to watching games that have a much smaller more tight knit commnuity but this just seems...off.


Also another thing about Dream - he recently got one of those weird yootoose thingies (I'm not spelling it right - they're like funko pops for youtubers) and like most youtubers and streamers (who are well established btw) I watch who've mentioned them talk about them as if they're kinda hard to get because you need to be a well known enough face in order for it to be marketable and then this Dream guy seems to randomly get one right out of the blue even though he's in a fairly niche area and isn't even a year old. Like *what* I call shenanigins

Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see on this guild when going to post this is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

body:
Minecraft speedruns are way too easy to fake. You could just create a world and delete level.dat, then when you "generate" it again with the same name and it'll look like it's a random seed but you'll already know what's in it.

Regardless, that can't be the sole reason for his popularity. Not everyone follows speedrunning, especially for Minecraft.

> Also another thing about Dream - he recently got one of those weird yootoose thingies (I'm not spelling it right - they're like funko pops for youtubers) and like most youtubers and streamers (who are well established btw) I watch who've mentioned them talk about them as if they're kinda hard to get because you need to be a well known enough face in order for it to be marketable and then this Dream guy seems to randomly get one right out of the blue even though he's in a fairly niche area and isn't even a year old. Like *what* I call shenanigins

Holy shit that's really weird. And Fundy already has a merch store, even though his first video ever was just uploaded this November. I think something strange is definitely going on here.

parent.body:
ok I don't know if this means anything but when I saw you mentioned Dream I went to check on his speedrun.com profile because he's currently the world record holder for random seed Minecraft and like, thats an *active* catagory (as in people are still trying to beat the record) so *surely* he's done a *bunch* of runs right?


...his profile was made 4 months ago, is *very* blank (most notably - there's no link to a streaming platform which is kinda normal nowadays), was last active a month ago (this also includes the site's forums but as I have no idea where the minecraft speedrunning community is based so that that with a pinch of salt) and has a total of *4* runs on it, all of which were world records in the same category and all have polished youtube videos showcasing them done in his standard style. For comparison the guy below him on the leaderboard whose account was made only a month before Dream's has *24* runs (and a *lot* more attempts) in more than one category, not all of them were world records and was last active a few hours ago.  

Now I don't follow minecraft speedrunning but I'd *love* to know if anyone who does has actually heard or interacted with Dream because this is...kinda weird. Like I know streamers will sometimes try world records for fun but for someone who doesn't seem to have a background in speedrunning to not only get the world record *3 times* and then *hold* it for over a month in a category that was updated as recently as yesterday seems *weird*. And look, maybe I'm overreacting because I'm used to watching games that have a much smaller more tight knit commnuity but this just seems...off.


Also another thing about Dream - he recently got one of those weird yootoose thingies (I'm not spelling it right - they're like funko pops for youtubers) and like most youtubers and streamers (who are well established btw) I watch who've mentioned them talk about them as if they're kinda hard to get because you need to be a well known enough face in order for it to be marketable and then this Dream guy seems to randomly get one right out of the blue even though he's in a fairly niche area and isn't even a year old. Like *what* I call shenanigins

post.body:
Sorry for the long post, but it requires a lot of explanation and data to be understood.

This all started two days ago when I found a new Minecraft YouTuber called "[Fundy](https://www.youtube.com/fundy)" while watching other stuff like AntVenom. Of course I saw it in the "suggested videos" sidebar. The majority of the stuff was stupid mods, and it seemed like a decent channel, although the 1M+ subscribers surprised me a little. But then I wondered why I hadn't seen them before, so I checked their older videos and...wait, that's not right, they only had 34 total, the first one being...*this December*?!

UPDATE: I found more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

[GeorgeNotFound](https://www.youtube.com/c/GeorgeNotFound/channels)

[Dream](https://www.youtube.com/Dreamm)

END UPDATE

I first assumed they just removed their older videos for some reason, so I did a bit more digging and found his [twitter account](https://twitter.com/fundylive). And behold, the video from this December really *was* the first video, at which point the channel had just hit 1k subscribers! No wonder I hadn't seen them before. But now I was really confused, as all the popular channels I've ever watched took an insanely long amount of time to build up their fanbase, with lots of videos in the process. Most popular channels took over a year to get the first 10k subs, and had average beginnings, but this guy just got hundreds of thousands of subs out of nowhere, reaching 1M in 6 months with only 34 videos, and their first videos were insanely high quality for a beginner *and* they and all the videos up till now got 1-5 million views every single time, all without any major SEO (search engine optimization) techniques! For comparison, the most popular channels usually get about 1-400k views per video. He literally has a 100% virality rate, as a *beginner*, which didn't sit right with me.

[1k subscribers in December, then another 1k+ the next day](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1212051427079667720)

[1 million views on his first few videos in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1216193854816313344)

[50k subs in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1221755156087353345)

[100k in March](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1240043074639876097)

[200k in April](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1255536659707412483)

[270k a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1261283315417518081)

After that it's literally about 100k per week

[400k a month later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1274152818891526147)

[700k 2 weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1277599336784891904)

[1 million a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1284901504281968641)

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch were created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he *did* have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

[Proof of older videos that were removed](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1178008635223339008)

For reference, here's the statistics of his *super legitimate* growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the ["living in a van" channel](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg).

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

> Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

> An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

> YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

> Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

> She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see on this guild when going to post this is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

body:
I thought that too but all his runs are verified and the oldest run contains a few false starts which I think are harder to cheat (because there's several worlds generated between the start of the video and the start of the run). That being said, the lack of a stream and a vod seems kinda weird in this day and age. Also, several of his videos have the fact that he's a "speedrunner" in the title, even if they're not related to speedrunning (see, his latest video for example) 

And I know its not the sole reason for his viewerbase but it's how I found out about him and he does kinda use the fact he's a "speed runner" as a selling point for his videos and I just thought it would be an intersting thing to bring up


Another thing I thought of - he's got some videos with *Notch* in them. Fucking *Notch*. I *dont* think thats something anyone could do on their own, even if they have a few mil subs and *especially* if they're really new and not a household name

One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

[Proof of older videos that were removed](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1178008635223339008)

For reference, here's the statistics of his *super legitimate* growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the ["living in a van" channel](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg).

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

> Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

> An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

> YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

> Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

> She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see on this guild when going to post this is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)
post.body_html:
Sorry for the long post, but it requires a lot of explanation and data to be understood.

This all started two days ago when I found a new Minecraft YouTuber called "Fundy" while watching other stuff like AntVenom. Of course I saw it in the "suggested videos" sidebar. The majority of the stuff was stupid mods, and it seemed like a decent channel, although the 1M+ subscribers surprised me a little. But then I wondered why I hadn't seen them before, so I checked their older videos and...wait, that's not right, they only had 34 total, the first one being...this December?!

UPDATE: I found more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

GeorgeNotFound

Dream

END UPDATE

I first assumed they just removed their older videos for some reason, so I did a bit more digging and found his twitter account. And behold, the video from this December really was the first video, at which point the channel had just hit 1k subscribers! No wonder I hadn't seen them before. But now I was really confused, as all the popular channels I've ever watched took an insanely long amount of time to build up their fanbase, with lots of videos in the process. Most popular channels took over a year to get the first 10k subs, and had average beginnings, but this guy just got hundreds of thousands of subs out of nowhere, reaching 1M in 6 months with only 34 videos, and their first videos were insanely high quality for a beginner and they and all the videos up till now got 1-5 million views every single time, all without any major SEO (search engine optimization) techniques! For comparison, the most popular channels usually get about 1-400k views per video. He literally has a 100% virality rate, as a beginner, which didn't sit right with me.

1k subscribers in December, then another 1k+ the next day

1 million views on his first few videos in January

50k subs in January

100k in March

200k in April

270k a few weeks later

After that it's literally about 100k per week

400k a month later

700k 2 weeks later

1 million a few weeks later

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch were created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he did have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

Proof of older videos that were removed

For reference, here's the statistics of his super legitimate growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the "living in a van" channel.

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see on this guild when going to post this is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

> YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

> Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

> She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see on this guild when going to post this is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)
post.body_html:
Sorry for the long post, but it requires a lot of explanation and data to be understood.

This all started two days ago when I found a new Minecraft YouTuber called "Fundy" while watching other stuff like AntVenom. Of course I saw it in the "suggested videos" sidebar. The majority of the stuff was stupid mods, and it seemed like a decent channel, although the 1M+ subscribers surprised me a little. But then I wondered why I hadn't seen them before, so I checked their older videos and...wait, that's not right, they only had 34 total, the first one being...this December?!

UPDATE: I found more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

GeorgeNotFound

Dream

END UPDATE

I first assumed they just removed their older videos for some reason, so I did a bit more digging and found his twitter account. And behold, the video from this December really was the first video, at which point the channel had just hit 1k subscribers! No wonder I hadn't seen them before. But now I was really confused, as all the popular channels I've ever watched took an insanely long amount of time to build up their fanbase, with lots of videos in the process. Most popular channels took over a year to get the first 10k subs, and had average beginnings, but this guy just got hundreds of thousands of subs out of nowhere, reaching 1M in 6 months with only 34 videos, and their first videos were insanely high quality for a beginner and they and all the videos up till now got 1-5 million views every single time, all without any major SEO (search engine optimization) techniques! For comparison, the most popular channels usually get about 1-400k views per video. He literally has a 100% virality rate, as a beginner, which didn't sit right with me.

1k subscribers in December, then another 1k+ the next day

1 million views on his first few videos in January

50k subs in January

100k in March

200k in April

270k a few weeks later

After that it's literally about 100k per week

400k a month later

700k 2 weeks later

1 million a few weeks later

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch were created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he did have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

Proof of older videos that were removed

For reference, here's the statistics of his super legitimate growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the "living in a van" channel.

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see on this guild when going to post this is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

[GeorgeNotFound](https://www.youtube.com/c/GeorgeNotFound/channels)

[Dream](https://www.youtube.com/Dreamm)

Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

> YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

> Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

> She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

body:
There isn't really any other possible reason for why they blew up the way they did. If you feel there is please tell us, but let's take a look at the facts:

They didn't use much SEO, and they just started making videos and had no fanbase prior to this, yet somehow already had professional equipment and channel art and everything. Their videos get suggested all over YouTube so that's why everyone watches them, YT is making them popular figures on purpose to make money off them. Look up their videos and you'll see many others that did the same videos, only for much longer and with more videos, but have much less views and subscribers. But for Fundy it only takes 34 of those videos and 6 months to get 1M subs and as many subscribers every week as those other channels get in 2 years, and millions of views on every single video, something which even (legit) famous channels cannot attain, thanks to YT shilling for him and Dream in everyone's suggestions. Check the numbers for yourself if you don't believe me.

Without YT's help Fundy would probably have at most 10k subs right now, and a couple thousand views per video, looking at the others that do similar videos. Perhaps less than that. It's a serious channel that could've built up a decent following over a long amount time, but the content is about average for that, so there's no excuse for how it exploded so quickly, and how every single video goes viral (and even if it was that golden it still would take a lot longer).

The only channels that I've ever heard of legit growing that fast are the extensions of existing popular ones, for obvious reasons. But even they don't feature the other things, such as getting millions of views on 100% of the videos or occupying half of everyone's suggestions feed for little reason. Anyone that gets a million views on their first video and magically gets hundreds of thousands of subs out of nowhere, and continues to get millions of views on every single video, even the more mundane ones, and constantly appears in the suggestions list should be a cause for suspicion. There's simply no other way that can happen

Sorry for the long post, but it requires a lot of explanation and data to be understood.

This all started two days ago when I found a new Minecraft YouTuber called "[Fundy](https://www.youtube.com/fundy)" while watching other stuff like AntVenom. Of course I saw it in the "suggested videos" sidebar. The majority of the stuff was stupid mods, and it seemed like a decent channel, although the 1M+ subscribers surprised me a little. But then I wondered why I hadn't seen them before, so I checked their older videos and...wait, that's not right, they only had 34 total, the first one being...*this December*?!

UPDATE: I found more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

[GeorgeNotFound](https://www.youtube.com/c/GeorgeNotFound/channels)

[Dream](https://www.youtube.com/Dreamm)

END UPDATE

I first assumed they just removed their older videos for some reason, so I did a bit more digging and found his [twitter account](https://twitter.com/fundylive). And behold, the video from this December really *was* the first video, at which point the channel had just hit 1k subscribers! No wonder I hadn't seen them before. But now I was really confused, as all the popular channels I've ever watched took an insanely long amount of time to build up their fanbase, with lots of videos in the process. Most popular channels took over a year to get the first 10k subs, and had average beginnings, but this guy just got hundreds of thousands of subs out of nowhere, reaching 1M in 6 months with only 34 videos, and their first videos were insanely high quality for a beginner *and* they and all the videos up till now got 1-5 million views every single time, all without any major SEO (search engine optimization) techniques! For comparison, the most popular channels usually get about 1-400k views per video. He literally has a 100% virality rate, as a *beginner*, which didn't sit right with me.

[1k subscribers in December, then another 1k+ the next day](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1212051427079667720)

[1 million views on his first few videos in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1216193854816313344)

[50k subs in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1221755156087353345)

[100k in March](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1240043074639876097)

[200k in April](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1255536659707412483)

[270k a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1261283315417518081)

After that it's literally about 100k per week

[400k a month later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1274152818891526147)

[700k 2 weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1277599336784891904)

[1 million a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1284901504281968641)

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch were created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he *did* have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

[Proof of older videos that were removed](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1178008635223339008)

For reference, here's the statistics of his *super legitimate* growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the ["living in a van" channel](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg).

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

> Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

> An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

> YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

> Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

> She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see on this guild when going to post this is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

body:
I think [Dream](https://www.youtube.com/Dreamm) is a genius, I believe he found a way to make viral Minecraft content. He said that [Mr Beast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MrBeast) was a massive influence on him and his TY content and that he watched a speech that Mr Beast made about how he makes TY vids get a lot of views or something like that I can't find the video. You can tell that at the beginning of his channel he made videos on all of the latest trends such as Pewdiepie, cursed and satisfying Minecraft vids, and his Unsolved Mysteries series. that will cause you to get a lot of viewers

Dream also has conections to [BadBoyHalo](https://www.youtube.com/user/thesaintsofgames) and [Skeppy](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCzMjRlKVO9XIqH_crIFpi6w) before Dream went on YT.

[GeorgeNotFound](https://www.youtube.com/c/GeorgeNotFound/channels) rides on Dreams success.


Fundy has the same growth as George


List of people who mass deleted videos and when

Fundy-- [-13,581 views deleted in June 2019](https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw)

George-- [-37,532 views deleted in August, and -11,101 views deleted in September 2019](https://socialblade.com/youtube/user/georgeeehdplays)

Dream; [-10,955 views deleted in February 2019](https://socialblade.com/youtube/user/dreamtraps)


I looked at Skeppy, Wadzee, BadBoyHalo, Sapnap, Dream, GeorgeNotFound, and Fundy

Skeppy, Wadzee, and BadBoyHalo look more normal than Dream, George, and Fundy.

post.body:
Sorry for the long post, but it requires a lot of explanation and data to be understood.

This all started two days ago when I found a new Minecraft YouTuber called "[Fundy](https://www.youtube.com/fundy)" while watching other stuff like AntVenom. Of course I saw it in the "suggested videos" sidebar. The majority of the stuff was stupid mods, and it seemed like a decent channel, although the 1M+ subscribers surprised me a little. But then I wondered why I hadn't seen them before, so I checked their older videos and...wait, that's not right, they only had 34 total, the first one being...*this December*?!

UPDATE: I found more of these YouTubers that follow the exact same pattern as Fundy!

[GeorgeNotFound](https://www.youtube.com/c/GeorgeNotFound/channels)

[Dream](https://www.youtube.com/Dreamm)

END UPDATE

I first assumed they just removed their older videos for some reason, so I did a bit more digging and found his [twitter account](https://twitter.com/fundylive). And behold, the video from this December really *was* the first video, at which point the channel had just hit 1k subscribers! No wonder I hadn't seen them before. But now I was really confused, as all the popular channels I've ever watched took an insanely long amount of time to build up their fanbase, with lots of videos in the process. Most popular channels took over a year to get the first 10k subs, and had average beginnings, but this guy just got hundreds of thousands of subs out of nowhere, reaching 1M in 6 months with only 34 videos, and their first videos were insanely high quality for a beginner *and* they and all the videos up till now got 1-5 million views every single time, all without any major SEO (search engine optimization) techniques! For comparison, the most popular channels usually get about 1-400k views per video. He literally has a 100% virality rate, as a *beginner*, which didn't sit right with me.

[1k subscribers in December, then another 1k+ the next day](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1212051427079667720)

[1 million views on his first few videos in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1216193854816313344)

[50k subs in January](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1221755156087353345)

[100k in March](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1240043074639876097)

[200k in April](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1255536659707412483)

[270k a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1261283315417518081)

After that it's literally about 100k per week

[400k a month later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1274152818891526147)

[700k 2 weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1277599336784891904)

[1 million a few weeks later](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1284901504281968641)

The other odd thing the twitter revealed is that his Twitch were created at the exact same time he started posting those videos, and he *did* have videos from before December but they were all removed immediately before the boom in popularity. He also started boasting about how big he would be. One of his first tweets was about quitting his job because he was "set for life" (implying he'd be making a fortune from YT) but it seems to have been deleted in the past few days. Keep in mind this was back in December, so it implies he knew this would happen ahead of time.

[Proof of older videos that were removed](https://twitter.com/FundyLive/status/1178008635223339008)

For reference, here's the statistics of his *super legitimate* growth over the past few months: https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw

This seemed strange to me, even though I'm not on YT, so I went on reddit and asked a few experienced and popular YouTubers what could be happening here.

I got an answer that Fundy could be an "industry plant". An industry plant usually refers to a musician, but after looking into this it's apparently a complaint among YouTubers as well. What YT will do is take someone random with a small following, and set them up with all the right equipment, ideas, format, etc. Then when they start posting those videos, YT makes sure they're all over the suggested videos section so everyone watches them and they make a ton of money off of them. As a side effect, that person receives major popularity extremely fast. Of course YT denies it, but they all do. Probably the most famous example of this is the ["living in a van" channel](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg).

This would make perfect sense here, and explain all the strange aspects of the channel that coincided with its unnaturally high growth. Getting millions of views on their first videos out of nowhere, and then having that continue to happen every single time, and getting a bunch of subscriptions out of nowhere are the main signs of this, especially if it's coming from places like the video suggestions.

Here's the exact response from a YouTuber with 300k+ subscriptions:

> Likely an industry plant. (Yes, YouTube has industry plants..... several actually)

> An industry plant is typically in reference to a musician. A label will basically take somebody random or with a very small following and invest a lot of money into them. Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

> YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

> Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

> She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see on this guild when going to post this is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)

body:
It would still be a lot of trial and error going viral, it is so even for people who've studied the algorithms for years and have it down to a science. There are even other channels that do the same videos as Dream and Fundy, but only get like 20k views and 100k subs. But Dream and Fundy literally have a 100% success rate.

And while Skeppy and BadBoyHalo may help explain Dream a little bit, they're both smaller than him. And the main new one is Fundy, who wasn't linked to anyone at all prior to suddenly appearing with a million subs. I have yet to hear even a partial explanation for how Fundy could have done it legitimately.

parent.body:
I think [Dream](https://www.youtube.com/Dreamm) is a genius, I believe he found a way to make viral Minecraft content. He said that [Mr Beast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MrBeast) was a massive influence on him and his TY content and that he watched a speech that Mr Beast made about how he makes TY vids get a lot of views or something like that I can't find the video. You can tell that at the beginning of his channel he made videos on all of the latest trends such as Pewdiepie, cursed and satisfying Minecraft vids, and his Unsolved Mysteries series. that will cause you to get a lot of viewers

Dream also has conections to [BadBoyHalo](https://www.youtube.com/user/thesaintsofgames) and [Skeppy](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCzMjRlKVO9XIqH_crIFpi6w) before Dream went on YT.

[GeorgeNotFound](https://www.youtube.com/c/GeorgeNotFound/channels) rides on Dreams success.


Fundy has the same growth as George


List of people who mass deleted videos and when

Fundy-- [-13,581 views deleted in June 2019](https://socialblade.com/youtube/channel/UCCE5NVlm0FhbunMMBT48WAw)

George-- [-37,532 views deleted in August, and -11,101 views deleted in September 2019](https://socialblade.com/youtube/user/georgeeehdplays)

Dream; [-10,955 views deleted in February 2019](https://socialblade.com/youtube/user/dreamtraps)


I looked at Skeppy, Wadzee, BadBoyHalo, Sapnap, Dream, GeorgeNotFound, and Fundy

Skeppy, Wadzee, and BadBoyHalo look more normal than Dream, George, and Fundy.

Giving them a ton of capital for music videos, production, etc. The label then makes money off of them and the musician typically receives a large following fast.

YouTube does the same thing, but tries to deny it (they all do). They will find somebody and set them up with the required equipment and such. Then they will purposely throw their videos into everyone's recommended section, making the content creator blow up in popularity and resulting in YouTube making a ton of money off of them. If you ever see a channel where someone is brand new yet has INSANE quality and their first video garners 1,000,000+ views and they magically have 500,000+ subscribers and continue to get 1,000,000-5,000,000 views per video it is likely that they are industry plant.

Here is an example: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaXEr4t_QBZBk3qlIlc2HRg

She "lives in a van" yet has extremely high quality videos, a great camera, editing software, etc... Has relatively garbage SEO tactics yet I believe she got over 1,000,000 subscribers in her first month ever on YouTube. She is an industry plant and people quickly caught on. She began deleting comments making those claims and never addressed it I believe.... It's a scummy practice and entirely unfair, but YouTube and other media companies do this as a quick and easy way to make a lot of money while simultaneously giving someone an advantage at their career above other people who are actually putting in a lot of effort.

What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is what's going on here? Is Fundy an industry plant?

Imo, "Industry plant" or not, I don't see any way this is legit.

(And of course the first thing I see on this guild when going to post this is about the Ruqqus Minecraft server now using Fundy's Impossible Difficulty plugin.)
post.title: Do you think the new MC YouTuber Fundy is just an industry plant?
